item.title: Tomb Garden and Pool of Cingius Iustinus
item.description: Province Dalmatia Province Description Location Salona Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden and Pool of Cingius Iustinus Keywords piscinae tombs epitaphs Garden Description A rock cut inscription at Salonae marks the spot where some time in the late second or third century Cingius Iustinus made a fishpond or pool (piscina) in the garden of his wife Aelia Licinia for her and for himself (fecit piscinam in horto Aeliae Liciniae coiugi incomparabili et sibi).

item.title: Palatial House in Insula 7 at Aventicum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Aventicum (Colonia Pia Flavia Constans Emerita Helvetiorum Foederata) Location Description The town was established in the Augustan period as the civitas capital of the Helvetii. At this time the orthogonal street grid was laid out. Most probably in AD 71, it became Colonia Pia Flavia Constans Emerita Helvetiorum Foederata. The town was destroyed or badly damaged around AD 260, and it was progressively abandoned thereafter.

item.title: Tomb Garden of Anonymous Gaul at Andematunnum
item.description: Province Germania Superior Province Description Location Andematunnum Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Garden of Anonymous Gaul at Andematunnum Keywords former reservoirs mausoleums orchards tombs Garden Description A famous inscription from the territory of the Lingonian Gauls (Langres) known only from a manuscript of the tenth century records the will of a local hunting enthusiast who built for himself a lavish mausoleum (cella memoriae) and equipped it with orchards (pomaria) and a reservoir (lacus) put in the care of two freedmen who are instructed to devote the revenues from them to upkeep of the tomb complex, and three landscape gardeners (topiarii) and their apprentices, each to be supported annually by the testator’s grandson, Sex.

item.title: Rural Villa at Sudeley/Spoonley Wood
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa at Sudeley/Spoonley Wood Keywords axial plan terrace gardens villae rusticae Garden Description The main residence of this rural estate in Gloucestershire, excavated in 1882, is of the winged corridor type (Fig. 1). From the north and south corners of the house, walls ran in a westerly direction to enclose an open courtyard (G in Fig. 1) approximately 65 meters wide and 45 meters deep from the outer boundary to the main entrance of the house.

item.title: Rural Villa at Latimer
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Latimer Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa at Latimer Keywords fences (site elements) orchards villae rusticae Garden Description Excavations at this country house in Buckinghamshire have produced evidence for gardens adjacent to the main residence in its latest phase dating to the beginning of the 4th century (Fig. 1). The house at the west is of the winged corridor type, fronted by a large courtyard bisected by a paved central drive with a banked edge.

item.title: Rural Estate at Gatcombe
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Gatcombe Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Estate at Gatcombe Keywords barrier walls Garden Description This site of a large rural estate about 9 hectares in size in Somerset is enclosed within a massive wall (Fig.1). item.title: Roman Palace at Fishbourne
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Fishbourne Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Roman Palace at Fishbourne Keywords colonnades palaces piscinae Garden Description Fishbourne Roman Palace was accidentally discovered during the digging of a water main trench in 1960. The discovery led to nine seasons of excavations (1961-69) that showed the site had developed from a military base at the time of the Roman invasion in AD 43 to a sumptuous palace by the end of the first century CE.

item.title: Tomb Painting at Chester
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Chester Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Tomb Painting at Chester Keywords funerary buildings tombs Garden Description Toynbee’s suggestion that a military tombstone from Chester depicting a row of three gabled buildings with stylized trees or shrubs planted in front of the two at the sides perhaps represents a tomb garden with tomb and flanking funerary buildings, though plausible, cannot in itself be taken to show that tomb gardens existed in Roman Britain; it would, however, suggest that the concept of planting at tombs was regarded as conventionally Roman and appropriate.

item.title: Rural Villa at Chedworth
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Chedworth Location Description Sublocation Sublocation Description Garden Rural Villa at Chedworth Keywords bathhouses (water recreation structures) mosaics (visual works) sherds villae rusticae Garden Description This Roman villa in Gloucestershire was partially excavated in the late 19th century, but only the built features and their mosaic floors appear to have been of interest to the Victorian diggers. Excavations in the courtyard conducted between 2000 and 2002 revealed that earlier excavators had not disturbed the courtyard.

item.title: Suburban Gardens at Camulodunum
item.description: Province Britannia Province Description Location Camulodunum Location Description Camulodunum began as an Iron Age settlement defended by dykes, a combination of V-shaped ditch and rampart created by the upcast earth. It extended from the Roman river on the south to the Colne on the north, a distance of some four kilometers. Within this larger area, a legionary fort was built after the Claudian conquest of Britain in AD 43. On the site of the fort, a veteran colony was planted in about AD 49 and given the name Colonia Victricensis, City of Victory.
